Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Beyond Acylation: New Methodology and Mechanistic Studies of Anhydrides for Stereoselective Synthesis
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this project, Prof. Jared Shaw of the University of California, Davis, funded under the Sustainable Chemistry, Engineering, and Materials (SusChEM) initiative (Chemical Synthesis Program, Chemistry Division), seeks to develop new strategies for assembling complex organic molecules in ways that maximize sustainability. Laboratory experiments will take advantage of the predictive power of computational chemistry in the design and development of new reactions. This project will enable the synthesis of organic molecules that might eventually become new medicines or other materials with useful properties while minimizing the negative impacts on the environment associated with many current techniques.

This project is centered on harnessing the potential of anhydrides to act as nucleophiles and to enable the synthesis of complex organic molecules with few byproducts. These transformations contribute to sustainability by occurring under mild conditions either in the absence of additional reagents or with the assistance of an organocatalyst, which serves as a benign alternative to transition metal-based catalysts. The ability of these new transformations to produce new organic architectures will be demonstrated in the construction of natural products derived from the Gelsimium species of plant. Natural products provide an over-riding theme for both research and outreach in this project. In addition to being an end-goal of the research, demonstrations of the properties of chemicals from plants as medicines enables this research to connect with the general public on many levels. Natural product-centered outreach includes an annual Science Caf√© to engage the general public, field trips for local high school students to the UC Davis Arboretum, and participation in an annual Chemistry Camp for Blind and Visually Impaired (BVI) junior high and high school students.

Performance_Institution.Name: Regents of the University of California

ProgramReference.Text: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The central objectives of this project were to develop new reactions based on the extended dipolar activity of cyclic anhydrides as both nucleophiles and electrophiles. Organic chemistry forms the basis for discoveries in medicine, materials research and many other fields. The ability to assemble useful organic molecules is predicated on understanding how certain functional groups (groups of atoms that confer certain reactivity) behave. One of the most fundamental concepts in organic chemistry relates to the “polarity” of functional groups, i.e. whether they donate or accept electrons when bonds are formed. Our research pushes the boundaries of this understanding for a certain function group (anhydrides) and enables the synthesis of new complex organic molecules.

Research published during this funding period achieved three general goals. First, the reactivity of a series of new cyclic anhydrides was explored, leading to new reactions that created complex heterocycles that will be useful for drug discovery, functional materials and other fields where rapid access to new organic molecules is required. Second, we completed the synthesis of a natural product target using the anion of a complex succinic anhydride as a nucleophile. This reactivity had not been observed previously and it opened up new doors for the use of electron-deficient imines in related reactions. Finally, building on these (and previous) results, we disclosed a catalytic variant of thermal reaction of imines and anhydrides. This last result opened up two new doors. This study suggested that asymmetric catalysis with chiral bases would be possible. Catalytic reactions reduce the waste produced in organic transformations and can often enable the preparation of one of the “hands” (stereoisomers, i.e. “right-” or “left-handedness”), which is required in many cases, e.g. for inhibition of a disease-causing enzyme. This study also documented peculiar modes of stereocontrol for chiral imines, which remain nearly totally unexplored. This latter impact formed the basis of a current (funded) grant from the NSF and a complementary avenue for stereoselective, or “hand-selective,” synthesis.

 

This project has, on the whole, resulted in several important outcomes that relate to the preparation of organic molecules. New reactivity has been observed for cyclic anhydrides and studied both in the laboratory and with computers, enabling the design of new ways to make molecules. The reactivity of these molecules is much more complex than anyone previously thought. This project has also revealed that chiral imines, i.e. reactive nitrogen-containing compounds with a particular “handedness” long assumed to react in direct analogy to their oxygen analogs, have certain previously unknown preferences that will be crucial in the design of new synthesis pathways. This latter discovery, once fully fleshed out in the current funding period, is likely to result in updates to the fundamental course material used in graduate education in organic chemistry.

The broader impacts of this project were vertical in nature, i.e. influencing the public across a range of age demographics. Elementary school children were inspired by presentations as a science fair. The general public, in an age distribution spanning six decades, gained broader scientific perspective in monthly science cafés. These events are held in a casual, welcoming environment and work to make science accessible to everyone. Davis Science Café, now in it’s sith year, regularly attracts 80 attendees and has nearly 1,000 “members” as judged but the email list and social media presence. Finally, undergraduate and graduate students were prepared to enter the private sector as well as additional training toward entering academia.

 


Last Modified: 11/30/2018
Modified by: Jared T Shaw
